Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Biventricular Pacing in Cardiac Surgery Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 20 patients at risk of low cardiac output post-coronary artery bypass grafting and/or valve surgery were enrolled.

Participants.evidence: 20 patients at risk of low cardiac output post-coronary artery bypass grafting and/or valve surgery were enrolled.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to biventricular pacing (n=11) or standard care (n=9).

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the effect of temporary biventricular pacing with optimized atrioventricular and interventricular delays on cardiac output in patients with left ventricular dysfunction undergoing cardiac surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Aortic flow was measured using an electromagnetic flowmeter within one hour post-cardiopulmonary bypass.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to biventricular pacing (n=11) or standard care (n=9).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Optimized pacing increased cardiac output by 13% compared to atrial pacing at matched heart rate (5.5±0.5 vs. 4.9±0.6 L/min; p = 0.003) and 10% compared to sinus rhythm (5.0±0.6 L/min; p = 0.019).

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
